media:group.media:title: Can Trees TALK?
media:group.media:description:
Weird video for this channel but it was fun to make. Go to https://establishedtitles.com/KKLEIN and help support the channel (and trees!). They are now running a massive early Black Friday Sale, plus 10% off on any purchase with code KKLEIN. Thanks to Established Titles for sponsoring this video!
Thanks to my patrons!! Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/user?u=73482298
Sources:
Curwood, S. (Host). (2018). "The Hidden Life of Trees". Living on Earth, 17/08/2018.
Gagliano, M., Vyazovskiy, V., Borb√©ly, A. et al. (2016). "Learning by Association in Plants". Sci Rep 6, 38427.
Grant, R. (2018). "Do Trees Talk to Each Other?". Smithsonian Magazine.
Haskell, D. (2017). The Songs of Trees. Viking Penguin.
Hathaway, M. (2022). What a Mushroom Lives For. Princeton University Press.
Hinchliffe, J. (2018). "Plants hate green thumbs ‚Äì science backs hands-off gardening approach". The Sydney Morning Herald.
Mannix, L. (2019). "Can trees learn? The plants are listening in, scientists say". The Sydney Morning Herald.
McClenaghan, B. (2019). "Talking Trees: How do Trees Communicate?". Let‚Äôs Talk Science.
NOTES [Note 1] ‚Äì Note the use of the passive voice here for the tree, as opposed to active for the dog. [Note 2] ‚Äì This is specifically about the conception in scientific literature, where an ‚Äúobjective‚Äù and ‚Äúnon-sensational‚Äù view has been emphasised for a long time. In the popular culture of nations around the world, trees have often been considered ‚Äúbeings‚Äù, as is argued in detail in Haskell (2017).
Chapters: 0:00 - Intro 1:37 - Trees Can Talk 3:24 - Debate 4:43 - Conclusion & Credits
Written and created by me Art & photography by kvd102 Music & additional graphics by me.
Translations: Leeuwe van den Heuvel - Dutch Wand_Platte - German
#trees #language

media:group.media:title: Let's Talk About Singular They.
media:group.media:description:
A sequel to the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iQNdkdqoIdw
Thanks to my patrons!! Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/user?u=73482298 Special thanks to Calvin for pestering me until I made this video.
Sources: Baron, D. (1981-2015). The Words that Failed: A chronology of early nonbinary pronouns. Baron, D. (1986). Grammar and Gender. New Haven. Baron, D. (2018). A brief history of singular ‚Äòthey‚Äô. Oxford English Dictionary Blogs. Fisher, A. (1745). A New Grammar [2nd ed. 1750]. Newcastle upon Tyne. Gerner, J. (1998). Singular and Plural Anaphors of Indefinite Personal Pronouns in Spoken British English. Corpora Galore: Analyses and Techniques in Describing English: Papers from the Nineteenth International Conference on English Language Research on Computerised Corpora. Graham, S. (2001). Sulawesi's fifth gender. Inside Indonesia. McWhorter, J. (1745). The Royal They: Fighting against the tyranny of pronouns. The New Republic. LaScotte, D. (2016). Singular they: An Empirical Study of Generic Pronoun Use. American Speech. 91 (1): 62‚Äì80. Miller, C. & Swift, K. (1980). The Handbook of Nonsexist Writing. New York. Harper & Row. Safire, W. (1985). On Language; You Not Tarzan, Me Not Jane. The New York Times. Wagner, S. (2003). Gender in English Pronouns: Myth and Reality. University of Freiburg. (1881). Detroit Free Press. May 13 edition. (2018). Collins COBUILD English Dictionary. (2022). they. The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language. Constitution of the United States of America. Article 1 ¬ß2.
Writings mentioned with examples of the singular ‚Äúthey‚Äù: Austen, Jane. (1814). Mansfield Park. Shakespeare, William. (p. 1623). The Comedy of Errors. Shaw, George Bernard. (1898). Plays Pleasant and Unpleasant. Anonymous writer. (c.1350). William and the Werewolf. Translated c. 1350-1375 to English from the original French written c. 1200.
NOTES FROM VIDEO: [Note 1] When I say ‚Äúis from‚Äù, I am arguing purely from a synchronic perspective ‚Äì I mean it as a shorthand for the fact that the plural mixed gender and plural masculine are the same, and distinct from the plural feminine in French. I am not making an argument from etymology here.
[Note 2] Wagner argues that ‚Äúthe choice of a supposedly masculine personal pronoun (him) said nothing about the gender or sex of the referent‚Äù in Middle English. However, I would argue that the association with the masculine over the feminine still applies. Wagner herself writes that this pronoun can be used for any combination of the genders ‚Äúmasculine‚Äù and ‚Äúneuter‚Äù, or sexes ‚Äúmale‚Äù and ‚Äúasexual‚Äù, deliberately excluding the ‚Äúfeminine‚Äù or ‚Äúfemale‚Äù. Despite being gender-neutral in some contexts, this pronoun was never epicene, not even in Middle English.
[Note 3] Note, of course, that ‚Äúman‚Äù was originally the word for ‚Äúhuman‚Äù, and only later came to mean ‚Äúmale adult‚Äù. In Old English, ‚Äúman‚Äù was ‚Äúwer‚Äù, and ‚Äúwoman‚Äù was ‚Äúwif‚Äù.
[Note 4] Joke.
[Note 5] Note the significantly lower percentages found only three years earlier, in Erdmann (1995), with singular ‚Äúthey‚Äù only being used in just under 50% of cases. This study was, firstly, done on Americans, who may be more biased against the singular ‚Äúthey‚Äù, and was also a study of written language, reflecting how the singular ‚Äúthey‚Äù is often seen as too informal by publishers, and therefore either avoided by authors, or changed by the editors.
[Note 6] Actually, in the examples given from Shakespeare‚Äôs Comedy of Errors and Austen‚Äôs Mansfield Park, the gender of the referent is known (masculine in the former case, feminine in the latter), but an epicene pronoun is used regardless. Go figure.
[Note 7] I am aware that people have been identifying as non-binary for a long time, even in Europe and colonial America. The sociology and history of this is worth looking into, but I am personally less interested in it and therefore didn‚Äôt want to go into the topic in the video.
[Note 8] When it is a subject, this ‚Äúsie/Sie‚Äù can be separated out into ‚Äúshe/feminine it‚Äù with the 3rd person singular verb ending, and ‚Äúthey/you‚Äù with the 3rd person plural verb ending. In the dative, the same split accords, as the former take the dative ‚Äúihr‚Äù and the latter the dative ‚Äúihnen/Ihnen‚Äù. When in the accusative or genitive, there is no difference in spoken language between the four. However, in writing, the formal ‚Äúyou‚Äù is distinguished from the others because it, and all its forms, are capitalised.
Chapters: 0:00 ‚Äì The Epicene ‚ÄúThey‚Äù 2:48 ‚Äì The Generic ‚ÄúHe‚Äù 5:28 ‚Äì The Non-Binary ‚ÄúThey‚Äù 7:21 ‚Äì Credits
Written and Created by me Art by kvd102 Music by me
Translations: Ferr - Indonesian D'ignoranza & Marco Lisoni - Italian Leeuwe van den Heuvel - Dutch Gerg≈ë Kulman - Hungarian Ray Karr - Spanish Ollie - French ÂçÉÈõ® Chisame - Standard Mandarin, Japanese Risto Kynk√§√§nniemi - Finnish Jafar - Arabic Nat√°lia - Brazilian Portuguese √Ålftanes - Cantonese Maymun - Turkish Eneko Andonegi - Basque
#theythem #nonbinary #historyofenglish #pronouns

media:group.media:title: In Defence of Grammatical Gender
media:group.media:description:
I finally talk about grammatical gender again ‚Äì there was so much to say, and I didn‚Äôt even get into phonoaesthetics! Talking of aesthetics, sorry for cripplingly bad audio.
Mistakes of the video: "il uomo" is incorrect, it's "l'uomo". *sigh*. And "kiuri" is a stupid typo, it's "kizuri".
Contact NMorrag (composer for outro): morragtimemusic@gmail.com Thanks to my patrons!! Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/user?u=73482298
Sources:
Alcock, K. (2000). " Grammatical noun class agreement processing in Kiswahili". Language and Speech.
Boroditsky, L. (2009). "How does our language shape the way we think?". Edge. [Retrieved 8/09/2022]
Contini-Morava, E. (2000). "Noun Class as Number in Swahili". Between Grammar and Lexicon. Ed. Contini-Morava, E. & Tobin, Y.
Corbett, G. (2013). "Number of Genders". The World Atlas of Language Structures Online. Leipzig: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. [Retrieved 14/09/2022].
Roch√©, M. (1992). "Le masculin est-il plus productif que le f√©minin ?". Langue fran√ßaise (96) 113‚Äì124.
Saussure, F. (1916). Cours De Linguistique G√©n√©rale. Paris: Payot.
Textor, C. (2022). Number of Chinese Communist Party members in China 2010/2021, by gender.
Williams, A., Cotterell, R., Wolf-Sonkin, L., Blasi, D., Wallach, H. (2021). "On the Relationships Between the Grammatical Genders of Inanimate Nouns and Their Co-Occurring Adjectives and Verbs". Transactions of the Association for Computational Linguistics (9) 139‚Äì159.
Office for National Statistics. (2022). Opinions and Lifestyle Survey 16/02/2022 to 13/03/2022.
Videos mentioned (in order of appearance):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=46ehrFk-gLk&t=82s by Tom Scott
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3B_uGsgXKdk by K Klein
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3AnG3tbwlIw&t=470s by Luke Ranieri
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7kV_bLrfUxs by Simon Roper
NOTES FROM VIDEO (in order of appearance):
Note 1: Here, I pronounce these words with stress on the prefix rather than the first syllable of the noun stem, where it should be. This was done to emphasise where these words are different; I don‚Äôt mean to give the impression that this is how these words should be pronounced in Swahili.
Note 2: I should have said ‚Äúanimate‚Äù here, not ‚Äúm-wa class‚Äù, because nouns of other classes are given ‚Äúm-wa‚Äù concords when they are animate. Hence, the speaker can conclude from hearing these concords only that the noun is animate, which narrows the options down to 7-15% of all nouns.
Note 3: Obviously, Mandarin Chinese does have gendered language in the sense that there are words to describe differences in gender. However, it does not have any grammatical gendered language, which English does have ‚Äì for instance, it would be considered incorrect to refer to a man as ‚Äúshe‚Äù. In modern usage, in writing, ‰ªñ (he) and Â•π (she) are usually differentiated, but this separation only occurred in the 1910s with the coinage of Â•π.
Note 4: However, note that there are counterexamples to this. In Swahili, many nouns describing people, even when they are in a class other than m-wa (class 1/2), use m-wa concords because their animacy takes priority over their morphological class. For instance, ‚Äúfundi‚Äù (‚Äúcraftsman‚Äù), plural ‚Äúmafundi‚Äù, is placed in the ‚Äúma‚Äù class (class 5/6) because of how its plural is formed, but still uses m-wa concords.
Note 5: I‚Äôm not saying that showing this kind of thing with emphasis is any worse inherently. It does work in English, even in writing with good use of italics. However, in speech it can definitely be confusing, with people often having to repeat themselves. Note that I am arguing from experience here.
Note 6: ‚Äúiel‚Äù, sometimes spelt ‚Äúielle‚Äù, (accusative ‚Äúlea‚Äù, dative ‚Äúlui‚Äù, emphatic ‚Äúellui‚Äù) is a French neopronoun meant for use by non-binary people. It is a merger of ‚Äúil‚Äù and ‚Äúelle‚Äù (and the accusative and emphatic forms are also merged from the accusative and emphatic forms of these pronouns).
Chapters: 00:00 ‚Äì Introduction 01:12 ‚Äì ‚ÄúGrammatical Gender Carries No Meaning‚Äù 02:46 ‚Äì ‚Äú‚Ä¶ and That‚Äôs a Bad Thing‚Äù 03:56 ‚Äì ‚ÄúGrammatical Gender Changes How You Think‚Äù 05:57 ‚Äì ‚ÄúMale‚Äù, ‚ÄúFemale‚Äù and ‚ÄúNeutral‚Äù 06:36 ‚Äì A Misanalysis of What Grammatical Gender Is 10:09 ‚Äì Trans People and Grammatical Gender 11:50 ‚Äì Credits
Written and Created by Me Art by kvd102 Outro Music by NMorrag
Translations: Luca Massenzio - Italian

media:group.media:description:

entry.title: When the Government Makes You Get a Surname

media:group.media:title: When the Government Makes You Get a Surname
media:group.media:description:
A look at the development of modern surnames in Sweden. It's actually pretty interesting if you ask me.
Note this is not an unexhaustive history of surnames in Europe, or even in Sweden.

Larsson, I. (2013) Namn och namnforskning. Ett levande l√§romedel om ortnamn, personnamn och andra namn. Ed. by Staffan Nystr√∂m (main ed.), Eva Brylla & al. Version 1. Uppsala.
Noreen, Erik & Adolf. (1907). Svenska familjenamn vid b√∂rjan av 1900-talet. Alfabetisk f√∂rteckning j√§mte statistiska och andra bilagor. Stockholm: Aktiebolaget Ljus.
Ryman, L. (2013) Namn och namnforskning. Ett levande l√§romedel om ortnamn, personnamn och andra namn. Ed. by Staffan Nystr√∂m (main ed.), Eva Brylla & al. Version 1. Uppsala.

entry.title: Counting the Phonemes in a Language

media:group.media:title: Counting the Phonemes in a Language
media:group.media:description:
A look at what phonemes are, and how to count them in a language, with a specific look at Standard Chinese. A sequel to my video "Chinese Doesn't Have Many Syllables": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BMI6Mbx8lbw
SORRY! The stress in French goes on the second syllable. I literally speak French (ish) I don't know how I would mess that up.
This video gets very technical somewhere around the halfway mark, so don't worry if you don't get all of it.
PLEASE NOTE: there are many, MANY more ways to analyse Standard Chinese phonemes. I'm not saying that these are the only three analyses, nor that they are the three most common, nor that they are the three best. Many of the features presented can be swapped around and pieced together to make new analyses (eg. getting rid of the zero-onset phoneme but not fusing the palatal/retroflex series). This is only meant to be an exercise and some thoughts about phonemic analysis.
Sources:
Chao, Yuen Ren. 1968. A Grammar of Spoken Chinese. Berkeley: University of California Press.
Duanmu, San (2000). The Phonology of Standard Chinese. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Lee, Wai-Sum; Zee, Eric (2003). "Standard Chinese (Beijing)". Journal of the International Phonetic Association. 33 (1): 109‚Äì112.
0:00 Introduction 1:45 What is a Phoneme? 3:50 Suprasegmental Phonemes 5:05 Segmental Phonemes 5:37 Phonemic Analysis of Standard Chinese 8:21 Ending/Outro
Written and Created by Me Art by kvd102 Thanks to my patrons!
Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/user?u=73482298

entry.title: Some Italian Nouns Switch Gender (And Why That's Interesting)

media:group.media:title: Some Italian Nouns Switch Gender (And Why That's Interesting)
media:group.media:description:
A discussion of grammatical gender in the context of the Romance (Latin-descended) languages, with a specific focus on Italian and Romanian. I also go into the origin of some unusual (within the European context) gender features in these languages.
I'm sorry for my pronunciation, especially of Romanian. I tried with the exact amount of effort required to neither be considered lazy nor be scolded for trying too hard and still failing.
Sources:
Bateman, Nicoleta; Polinsky, Maria. "Romanian as a Two-Gender Language"
Petrucci, Peter R. 1993. Slavic features in the history of Romanian. Doctoral dissertation, USC.
Rosetti, Alexandru. 1965. Linguistica. The Hague: Mouton.
The film is "Life of Brian" by Monty Python. And yes, I'm aware that the clip I showed is technically about conjugations and I was technically talking about declensions: don't bully me, it's a funny *reference*.
Written and Created by Me Art by kvd102 Special thanks to I.M. for all their help with the Romanian and Italian in this video :)
00:00 - L'italiano 00:20 - Grammatical Gender 03:00 - Romanian Grammatical Gender 04:59 - Heterogeneity 05:53 - Latin Grammar Time 06:49 - Conclusion
Translations: Icaro Vega - Spanish palpatinezw - Standard Mandarin Leeuwe van den Heuvel - Dutch

entry.title: Pronouns That Change By Time (And Why You Shouldn't Find Them Weird)

media:group.media:title: Pronouns That Change By Time (And Why You Shouldn't Find Them Weird)
media:group.media:description:
A discussion of temporal pronouns, in the context of the Senegambian language of Wolof (spoken chiefly in Senegal and the Gambia).
Written and Created by Me Art by kvd102
Interested in learning Wolof? Check out Mor Gueye: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCm5dJZCDO6aWM6inDHwfV9Q
Translations: Leeuwe van den Heuvel - Dutch
